dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH-PITCHED WHINES. LOUDER AND LOUDER. MORTARS race through the air and EXPLODE in the distant jungle. Sol- diers -- black, white, Oriental -- curse and mutter in French, German, Australian and American as they reload. COMPUTER KEYS POUND -- the letters leap across the screen THE MOTABA RIVER VALLEY, BELGIAN CONGO (ZAIRE), 1960.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: carrying a bucket of water from the Motaba River rushes past the Mercenary Army to --

dialogues.speaker: CAMP INFIRMARY
dialogues.text: Where he replaces the towel on the forehead of a fever- ish, delirious AUSTRALIAN MERCENARY with a cold new one.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN MERCENARY
dialogues.text: Gimme somethin' for the bleedin' pain. C'mon, mate, help me. The Mercenary tries to lift himself out of his stretcher. Can't. He's too weak. His skin is yellow and covered with blisters that look like chicken pox.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (checking the soldier's temp) He's still over a hundred and six. Why can't we bring it down? The black African army physician, DR. RASWANI, looks on, helpless. Suddenly, the Australian emits a sharp cry. His eyes roll back, and he begins convulsing. Before Raswani can even reach into his bag for medecine, the Mercenary is dead. Raswani and his Nurse stare with horror. The DRONE of a CHOPPER grows LOUDER as a Bell Z180 ap- pears over the edge of the forest and kicks up a storm of dust as it lands. Raswani and the Nurse run to meet it. In their eyes, hope. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two space-suited figures emerge from the chopper, their faces hidden by thick green plexiglass shields. The U.S. flag is emblazoned on the side of their helmets, which also display their ranks. The much taller man is a lieutenant whom we'll know as McCLINTOCK. Through his visor, we can just make out his pock-marked, angular face. The shorter, pear-shaped man is a CAPTAIN. We can't see his features, only the reflection of horn- rimmed glasses.

dialogues.speaker: RASWANI
dialogues.text: Have you brought the medicines?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: RASWANI
dialogues.text: Why the hell didn't you bring them? Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: INFIRMARY
dialogues.text: The two space-suited figures follow Dr. Raswani past soldier after soldier infected with the same disease.

dialogues.speaker: RASWANI
dialogues.text: Thirty deaths yesterday, eighteen the day before, the disease is killing our men faster than enemy bullets. The Captain stops at a young AMERICAN MERCENARY'S cot. He's shaking with fever. His skin is mottled and looks like the pulp of an orange. His voice is a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN MERCENARY
dialogues.text: Take me home, Captain... Get me outta this shithole. Please, I wanna see my girl. The American Mercenary reaches out with his arms to the Captain, who shrinks back, not wanting to be contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: We'll get you home, soldier. First, I need a tissue sample. He pulls from his black bag a long metal syringe and plunges the biopsy needle deep into the man's liver. He places the needle in an aluminum test tube and seals it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN MERCENARY
dialogues.text: Promise me you'll get me home. Promise me, Goddamit! A long uneasy beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: We'll get you home. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: TWO SPACE-SUITED U.S. ARMY FIGURES
dialogues.text: boarding their chopper, Dr. Raswani and his Nurse standing by.

dialogues.speaker: RASWANI
dialogues.text: Not just supplies, but doctors and nurses. And suits like yours to protect us. This disease spreads too fast.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The plane tonight will bring everything. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CHOPPER
dialogues.text: ascending above the camp. Lt. McClintock and the Captain look out the window at the campsite. McCLINTOCK It's viral. There's no way to stop it. It could spread all over the world. We can't see the Captain's face, but feel his remorse. So can McClintock: McCLINTOCK If you'll excuse my bluntness, sir, you can't go halfway on this one.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Don't ever -- ever -- tell me what I have to do. Cut TO:  TSHOMBE CAMPSITE —- DUSK Dr. Raswani gives a shot to the American Mercenary, who looks terminal.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RASWANI
dialogues.text: This will help the pain. The Male Nurse rushes up.

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: They're coming.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN MERCENARY
dialogues.text: I knew... they'd come back... I knew. Help me up. Help me -- Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: RASWANI
dialogues.text: ThE Male Nurse, and dozens of soldiers rush across the forest to the makeshift runway beside the camp. In the distance a camouflaged DC-3 is rapidly approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PILOT, no more than 21, sees the soldiers celebrating their arrival down on the runway. His hand is on the green bomb release lever.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: I can't. McClintock is in the copilot's seat. McCLINTOCK It's either them or us. He puts his hand on the green release lever. Hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: You can't either.

dialogues.speaker: ON GROUND
dialogues.text: Dr. Raswani and the soldiers stare at the plane, coming in too high for a landing.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE PLANE
dialogues.text: McClintock squeezes the green lever. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bomb cannisters under the wing open up, releasing a thick cloud of yellow cyanide gas.

dialogues.speaker: ON GROUND
dialogues.text: Screams of agony rip out as Raswani and the soldiers convulse and die. The plane shoots over the treetops, spraying the ground below like a crop duster. Then the plane arcs and approaches again.

dialogues.speaker: OVER RUNWAY
dialogues.text: littered with the dead, the plane releases a waxy grey cloud. One second. Two seconds. An eerie stillness. The CLOUD EXPLODES in a huge inferno. The plane releases more and more napalm, burning the jungle for miles. The CRIES of ANIMALS caught in the fire pierce the night. Flames shoot up trees a hundred feet high. PULL BACK to show the whole forest ablaze. A long beat, then at the very LEFT CORNER OF the FRAME, a MONKEY with a black and white coat (a Colobos monkey) emerges from the fire, looks back at its mate, threatened by the flames. The Colobos jumps up and down, baring its teeth, SCREAMING. The fire moves relentlessly forward. The monkeys dart to safety. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOTABA RIVER VALLEY
dialogues.text: A metal syringe burned to a molten shard lies beside a mortar launcher, twisted and deformed like some bizarre modern sculpture. PULL BACK to reveal acre after acre, mile after mile of nothing but ashes and carcasses of burnt-out trees. Not a single living thing remains. FADE OUT and ROLL CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: TREETOPS
dialogues.text: A wind rippling through treetops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE RAINFOREST
dialogues.text: Brilliant streams of orange and purple, the last rays of the setting sun, dance across the sky and penetrate the vapor cloud above the rain forest. Unworldly silence. Shattered by: Giant TREES CRASHING to the ground. TRACTORS ROAR, CHAINSAWS REV with a penetrating whine. Huge trees living undisturbed for hundreds of years topple to earth, their roots ripped from the soil. REVEAL the army of construction workers clearing a path for the new road linking Kinshasa with Bangui. White foremen bellow orders in French at their black workers, including: MORAZU: a seven-foot tall Goliath with mischievous eyes. He PUNCHES on his CHAIN SAW and RIPS into another tree. A cloud of wood dust envelops him.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD
dialogues.text: ROAR by overhead, their machine gunners searching for guerilla activity.

dialogues.speaker: TWO COLOBOS MONKEYS
dialogues.text: a mother and her daughter, whom we'll know as Betsy. Betsy plays with a fat, round jackfruit, kicking it and rolling it every which way. Her mother watches the construction workers warily. Morazu hums as he pulls a huge tree limb off the road and into a thick patch of brush where he comes face to face with Betsy. Morazu smiles. He takes a long piece of sweetened bread from his pocket and lays it down right in front of the young monkey. Betsy eyes it warily.

dialogues.speaker: MORAZU
dialogues.text: (softly) Take it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat. Betsy takes the bread, examines it careful- ly, finally takes a bite. Morazu grabs her. BETSY struggles, thrashing and SCREAM- ING. Morazu pins her hands behind her back. She spins around and sinks her teeth into his finger. He lets go with a shriek and swears at Betsy, who disap- pears with the bread. STAY WITH Morazu as he returns to his work. He sucks the blood out of the small wound. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morazu gets off a bus by a small muddy river and walks slowly toward his village of about fifty mud-thatched huts. Pain in his back makes him wince. We see him UP CLOSE: his eyes are red and his skin is pale. He's sweating. He stops at the village well and takes a drink. Other villagers come up to say hello, and Morazu greets them wearily, dipping his cup back in the water for another drink. The villagers drink too. DISCOVER in the background: the tribal medicine man, the "ju-ju man." Streaks and circles of paint cover his skin. He watches the excitement surrounding Morazu's return. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: RAIN FOREST
dialogues.text: A small group of Colobos monkeys including Betsy and her mother run swiftly through the forest. Suddenly, BETSY CRIES OUT. Her foot is snagged in a trap. Before her mother can respond, she's pulled high into the air into a bamboo cage. The DOOR SNAPS SHUT. BETSY SCREAMS in fear and pain, hanging upside down -- Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: The Colobos monkeys scatter as VOICES APPROACH, REVEALING two TRIBESMEN pulling a small wagon. The men chatter as they lower the cage holding Betsy onto the cart. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP LUCIANO PAVAROTTI singing a love song from “La Boheme" and... Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: HUMAN SKULL
dialogues.text: wearing Porsche sunglasses and an Army Colonel's hat. COMPUTER KEYS POUND: "Frederick, Maryland, August 19."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP the VOICE of a MAN SINGING along with the GREAT TENOR. CONTINUE PANNING OVER the room: the skull gives way to a full skeleton wearing a star-spangled red-white- and-blue bow-tie and carrying an umbrella over its fore- arm. CONTINUE PAST the oak rolltop desk. MIKE GILLESPIE, about 40, keeps singing as he reads through a lengthy typed report, making notes in the margin. LUCIANO hits a high C. Gillespie reaches for it... and misses badly. DOGS WHINE O.S., probably in closer harmony to Luciano than Gillespie. He's not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I rescue you from certain death and instead of gratitude, you mock me. His two WOLFHOUNDS, Olser and Harvey, GROVEL on the floor contritely, each with a worn shoe in his mouth. Behind them we see the rest of Gillespie's living/dining room. His townhouse is spartan; it needs a woman's touch. Un- packed boxes stand in the corner beside a treadmill.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: That can't go unpunished. No Letterman for three nights. The dogs wag the running shoes. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: OLD CREEK PARK, (FREDERICK, MARYLAND)
dialogues.text: Gillespie, puffing, a weekend runner, strains to keep up with the DOGS. They BARK excitedly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (reaching into his pockets) Okay! Okay! Without breaking stride, he throws what look like sticks high into the air. The dogs jump and catch the objects in their mouths and race back to Gillipsie. We see they're old stethoscopes with thick rubber tubing. Gillespie lets them fly again. He laughs at their eager- ness and keeps running, sprinting now, trying to prove to himself that he's still young. Suddenly -- a PHONE RINGS. Without breaking stride, he pulls a cellular phone from his pocket:

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Dr. Gillespie... How many dead?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie's boss, GENERAL BILLY FORD, MD, is a heavy-set man in his early 60's with thinning hair, piercing, in- telligent grey eyes and a warm smile. Scattered all around his office are cages filled with frogs and rep- tiles. As he talks on the phone, he's feeding a green- horned toad some dead flies.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Almost an entire village.

dialogues.speaker: FORD WITH GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: still running.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Is is Lassa Fever? Ebola? What?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: How the hell do I know? I'm the bureaucrat, you're the detective, remember? All I know is State wants us to lend a hand and when the Secretary talks, I listen. And when I talk, you listen. You're Code Red. The plane's leaving at 01:30. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Gillespie hangs up, out of breath... excited. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie and the dogs pull into the driveway of a comfor table two story colonial home, passing a "For Sale" sign on the front lawn pasted with a "Sold" sticker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie knocks. The DOGS BARK excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it? The dogs recognize the voice and jump against the door.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Mike. ROBERTA "ROBBY" KEOUGH, an attractive, intelligent woman in her mid 30's, opens the door a few inches, until the latch LOCK CHAIN SNAPS tight. The dogs try to push inside.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (smiles; delighted) Hey, guys! But when she looks at Gillespie, she's guarded.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Robby, I know I'm the last guy you'd do a favor for, but I've got no one else to ask.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: My lawyer said not to talk to you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Then just listen. I gotta go to Zaire. Robby shakes her head, "No, no way." (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Put 'em in a kennel.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: So they can die of some weird disease like Stripes did? She mouths the word "no."

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: -- Look, Robby, if I had any other choice, I wouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You should've let me have them. You can't take care of them. Beat. Robby's torn. The dogs nuzzle against her leg.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I won't be gone long.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You know I'm moving to Atlanta -- they want me to start in four days.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I'll be back before that.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Four days is four weeks -- to you. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: It wasn't all my fault, Robby.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (quietly) I know. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I'll look after them on one condition: if you're not back in four days, they're mine. Gillespie doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Okay. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: In writing. She unlatches the door and moves inside. The dogs race after her. Gillespie enters...

dialogues.speaker: FRONT HALL
dialogues.text: overflowing with moving boxes, some sealed, others waitin to be packed. Gillespie feels awkward, a stranger in his own home. She hands him a prescription pad. He crosses off her nameplate, "Roberta Keough, MD," and starts writing while Robby enters...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, c'mon! They follow her in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Guess what I got? The DOGS BARK excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Damn straight! She opens the freezer, grabs a couple of frozen bagels an flips them to the DOGS. They catch the bagels and start CHOMPING.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I missed you guys so much. Gillespie hands her the note.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (reading it) 'I, Michael Gillespie, agree that if I'm not back in exactly four days from now, the ownership of my dogs, Osler and Harvey, will go to Roberta Keough.' (handing it back) Time and date it. He does. She points to a huge box on the kitchen table: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: That's stuff from med school... Some of it's yours. I don't know if you want any of it. He fishes through it, shoving aside old medical books and equipment. He finds an old wood stethoscope with thick rubber tubing. He shoves in into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Got a place yet?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: An apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: The first thing you'll do is spend the whole night unpacking... You'll stay up 'til dawn but you'll get everything in its place.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Probably.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Nothin' in my life has been organized since you left, Robby. Beat. She's surprised at his admission. And un- comfortable. So's he. He continues searching through the box and pulls out... A photo taken during their honeymoon cruise: they're both smiling radiantly as they hold between them a trophy of a dancing couple.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Y'know, this is the only evidence on Earth that I was ever graceful. He checks her reaction. There is a hint of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Take it.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Nah, people might see it... get the wrong impression. He drops the photo back in the box and moves toward the door. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Four days.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Or less. As we hear the front DOOR OPEN and SHUT, HOLD ON Robby: a hint of regret. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: ANDREWS AIR BASE, MARYLAND
dialogues.text: COMPUTER KEYS POUNDING: "Andrews Air Base, Maryland." Flood lights illuminate a huge C5A transport plane waiting on the runway, its nose cocked open exposing its innards to the pouring rain. Several enlisted men rapidly wheel equipment into the open hatch. A private pushes a dolly loaded with boxes with the red cross emblem up the ramp. DR. ISAAC "IZZY" BERMAN, a short, bald Army Major in his late 30's directs traffic.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Blood in the freezer over the right wing. C'mon! Gut it! We're late. The private grunts and pushes the dolly slowly up the ramp. Izzy lends a hand, and the two of them run it up the ramp. Mike Gillespie, dressed in a uniform, climbs down from the cockpit. Now we see his rank: Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Where the hell's Yaffe?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: His wife... she's due tomorrow. I put him on leave.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: We need him now! Who's going to read the electron micrographs?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I will. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: You can't even read a Playboy pinup.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: He said he'd get a guy to fill in.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: We can't wait. A Jeep drives across the tarmac, toward them and comes to a park a short distance away. The Driver scurries out to open the passenger door to let -- General Ford get out.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What does he want? The driver pulls two suitcases out of the Jeep and follows Ford into the plane.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm comin' along, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Sir, we're going into very dangerous territory.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I'm well aware of the dangers.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Beggin' your pardon, General, I don't think you are. You've had only the most cursory training on how to avoid contamination. Concerns for your safety would distract us.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Nothing distracts you, Colonel. You won't even know I'm there.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm not comfortable --

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Mike, have a little compassion for an old man who's been rotting behind a desk. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For once I'd like to be there when one of these buggers hits. You're not going to tell me I can't go, Colonel, are you?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Good. I feel wanted, now. (beat) I get airsick in the back. I'll be up with the pilot. As they watch him move forward and out of sight: Gillespie Gillespie Gillespie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pilot,

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: The guy wouldn't know a virus from a Barbie Doll. I'm not lookin' after him. He's yours.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: All of a sudden, playing golf and pushin' papers isn't good enough. Damn, when I'm his age, that's all I'm gonna want to do. flips a coin, covers it over his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Heads. No! Tails. lifts his hand and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Fuck! grabs the phone to the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Rafferty, rock and roll with this bird. It CAPTAIN RAFFERTY, checks General Ford, nestled in safely behind him.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: (into headmike) T minus sixty seconds.  17.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW
dialogues.text: Gillespie pulls a lever and the hatch starts to close.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Wait! Mike follows his eyes out to the --

dialogues.speaker: TARMAC
dialogues.text: where a BLACK MAN carrying a duffel bag is sprinting toward them at incredible speed, like a ghost through the pelting rain. Berman swings the lever down and the hatch starts to open but the Man doesn't wait for it to lower completely. Without breaking stride, he leaps the four feet onto the plane and slides to a stop right in front of Gillespie. He steadies himself and salutes:

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (BLACK MAN)
dialogues.text: Captain Walter Salt reporting, sir. Izzy smiles. He looks at Gillespie, who is impressed but won't show it.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to be late, sir. I was wrapping up some tests in my lab --

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: -- Strap in. The huge JET ENGINES come to life. Gillespie, Berman, and Salt strap themselves into the row of jump seats along the fuselage. Issy is filled with the excitement of a young kid who can't believe his luck:

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You're not the football player from West Point, that Salt?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: The same, sir.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I thought you had the Heisman sewed up 'til you hurt your knee. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane 18.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: You and my mother, Major... I was never that good. But thank you for saying so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Don't call me sir. The only one who does that is the Colonel here. Everyone else calls me Izzy.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Izzy, sir?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: My mother calls me Isaac, but I hate it. I pitched for my high school team. My dad thought I was gonna be another Dizzy Dean. So he called me 'Izzy.'

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, Izzy, sir. surges forward and taxis down the runway.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I want to know just one thing. Can you read electron micrographs as well as you can run?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I'm not sure how to assess the question --

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: -- Just say ‘yes, sir,' Captain. Whatever the Colonel asks, you just say ‘yes, sir.' That's how we keep him under control.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen filovirus infection in a human being?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: It's about as pretty as goin' naked up the middle against the Dallas Cowboys. (CONTINUED )
I grew up on the South Side of Chicago, sir. Whatever it i I can handle it.

dialogues.text: first carries a gunship flying a River that (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On the river: a Zairean Army patrol boat cruises down- stream, looking for guerrillas. The machine gunner swivels his cannon around at the two choppers. The machine gunner looks up at the U.S. Army insignia and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Izzy slips the clear helmet over General Ford's head. PULL BACK to reveal: The General covered from head to toe in BL-4 bio- safety suit. Salt, dressed the same, looks on, amused.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: (panicking) How do you breath in here?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (laughs) With a respirator. Positive pressure's what you want. Keep those buggers out. Izzy flips the switch on Ford's respirator, which sucks air out of the atmosphere, filters it, and pumps it into the suit. Ford starts to swell up like the Pillsbury doughboy.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: And I thought it was a hassle wearin' a tie all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie, now suited up in full biosafety gear, but holding his helmet in his hands, sits beside the CHOPPER PILOT. In the distance, we see a village in which numerous huts are burning.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: We got a lot of equipment. You're gonna have to get us in close.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: I... I don't want to get no disease, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Then don't kiss me, Sergeant. Cut TO:  21.

dialogues.speaker: CHOPPERS
dialogues.text: throwing up a storm of dust as they sweep down to the ground on the perimeter of the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie, Salt, Berman and Ford stand by the door, ready to get out as soon as the chopper puts down. Gillespie has to shout at Salt over the sound of the

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Captain Salt, if you fail to observe strict decontamination protocol, three things can happen. First, you can be court-martialed. Second, you can die from this horrible disease. Third, and worst of all, you can incur my displeasure. You got it?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: If one of us gets sick, we all get sick. (turns to Ford) And I didn't come here to die.

dialogues.speaker: BURNING HUTS
dialogues.text: juxtaposed against the U.S. Army choppers disgorging the U.S. Army Infectious Disease Team -- blue space- suited figures with the U.S. flag emblazoned on their arms and helmets. The ju-ju man remains high on the cliff above the village, chanting and wailing, burning an offering to the gods. The U.S. Army Team approaches the village through the smoky haze, and we see -- Two different worlds juxtaposed -- men in spacesuits and a man in a loincloth. Gillespie, followed by Berman, Salt and Ford, moves across the village which now looks devastated and deserted except for a few remaining huts and a small cinder block building with an old Volkswagen van, marked with a red cross, parked out front. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ford walks slower taking everything in, appalled at what he sees. The U.S. Army team enters the cinder block hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, slender, bespectacled black man in his late forties -- DR. IWABI -- head of the Zaire Infectious Disease Heath Agency -- and his NURSE, protected only by a smock, a surgical mask, and gloves, gives comfort to a young woman who's dying.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Doctor Iwabi? I brought blood, plasma --

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: -- You're too late.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I came as soon as I could.

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: It wouldn't have mattered when you came. This one is different -- worse than Lassa, worse even than Ebola. It strikes and kills so fast. The young, the healthy, everybody.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Who was the index case?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: A road construction worker.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: How did he get it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: We don't know. He died three days ago. Salt moves ahead to the next bed and pulls aside the thin mosquito curtain to inspect the patient. Ford is right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: God... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The corpse's eyes are yellow and his flesh, speckled with hemmorrhages, looks like pulp. Blood oozes from his nose and his nipples. Ford turns away in horror.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: (retches) I'm gonna be sick. He starts to rip off his mask. Gillespie grabs his arms.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Keep you helmet on, Goddamit!

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I can't breath. Salt vomits in his helmet. Rips it off. He rushes out. Izzy moves after him.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Put him in quarantine. Now!

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: You don't need to.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: It's not spread in the air.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: (pulls down his mask) There's no cough. Or we'd all be dead. For days we've been working with only these masks. They can't keep out a particle as small as a virus.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Could any infected person have gotten out of this village and spread it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: The incubation period is only one or two days. The mortality is one hundred percent. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If anyone got out, they are dead, or will be soon. And if they have spread the disease, we will know rather quickly.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Finding the host is the only way to control the spread. Our only hope is that this is like most viruses and that it has to live in a host, an animal, to which it's adapted over thousands of years. And that animal host has developed antibodies to protect itself against the virus. If we can identify that animal host, and harvest its antibodies, we can use them to fight the disease in humans.

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: There are a hundred thousand species of animals and insects in this rain forest. The construction worker could have been in contact with any one of them. Where do I start?

dialogues.speaker: GILLEPSIE
dialogues.text: General, tell him that our government will help with money, personnel supplies, whatever it takes. Ford hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Of course, we'll do whatever we can. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a SINGLE-FRAMED TIME LAPSE SHOT, dawn arrives in the Motaba Valley. FADE UP the hundreds of sounds of the rain forest ANIMALS. There is something primeval about this vista; this surely must be what the Garden of Eden looked like, except for the... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Plumes of black smoke which waft up from the blackened, smoldering huts, each one the home of someone who has no died from this terrible virus. Two African orderlies carry a stretcher bearing the dead body of a villager. They slide it onto a funeral pyre already burning with bodies. Gillespie, Ford and Dr. Iwabi make their way to the choppers where Berman and Salt are loading into the hold plexiglass cases of blood samples.

dialogues.speaker: ON CLIFF OVERHEAD
dialogues.text: The ju-ju man chants. He seems to float above the funeral pyre like a mirage.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: He's asking for forgiveness from the Gods of the forest. They're angry because they've been awoken from their sleep by the men building the road. These deaths are their punishment.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Why isn't he sick?

dialogues.speaker: DR. IWABI
dialogues.text: He stayed in his cave all week and greeted his visitors with poison darts.

dialogues.speaker: GILLEPSIE
dialogues.text: (a sense of foreboding) It was as if... as if he knew what was coming. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading home. Ford reads a hand-written paper Gillespie's just handed him and gets irate. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie' 26.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: A memo to the CDC to issue a warning to every physician in the United States to be on the look-out for this disease? What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: A safeguard, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? Within a week we'll know if this thing burned itself out in that village, just like Iwabi said --

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: -- And if Iwabi's wrong? American doctors should be warned so cases can be quarantined. Sir, this one is different --

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: -- You're a smart guy, Gillespie, but you can't write a memo to the CDC which says the sky is falling.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (sharply) We should do nothing?

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Did I say that, Colonel? (beat) We will monitor the situation in Africa, and if this virus reappears, we will act with all our resources, not just to protect the American people but the people of the world. You will destroy this memo. That's an order. s frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NATIONAL AIRPORT, (WASHINGTON)
dialogues.text: Robby is moving forward in the boarding line, and Mike is walking be side her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: You asked for four days and four days it was... last night.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: It was a bad virus... Cut me some slack.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I cut you ten years of slack. I'm not giving you the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Stop joking. Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: I shipped them this morning.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: You did not. ON her face: a triumphant smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: It's better for them. And for you. I'll be there to feed them and take care of them. You won't have to feel guilty. She moves past the gate. Gillespie's stuck behind it. Screaming after her:

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I'm coming to Atlanta... I'm takin' ‘em back.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Dream on. HOLD ON Gillespie's dismay as she disappears. Cut TO: INT. MAIN CORRIDOR OF M.I.D.U. Mike walking briskly down the main corridor. Two M-16 toting security guards salute as he passes by. He reaches six-inch thick metal doors, closed tight. He slides his ID card into the optical reader. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The computer screen above it prints out the words, "Colonel Michael Gillespie." A digitized voice booms from the WALL SPEAKER:

dialogues.speaker: WALL SPEAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How-are-you-today-Doctor-Gillespie?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Piss ass good. And you?

dialogues.speaker: ON COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: We see Gillespie's voice print. The doors spring open. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie going up in the elevator past the four floors o glassed-in laboratories. At the first level, workers wear civilian clothes. At the second level, they wear respir- ators. At the third level, they wear body suits, and at the fourth level they wear biosafety suits. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Izzy strip off their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Admit it, for chrissakes: The dogs will get better care with her than they got with you.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: That really cheers me up.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You think cause we're friends I should ignore reality.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I think cause we're friends you might show some tact. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You were gone so often that when you were home... you spoiled ‘em. Robby keeps an even keel.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Hey, she's available...

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Don't think I haven't thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: You're just what she's looking for. Mr. Stability. Three wives in five years.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Two. I never married Sherry. I liked her too much... Izzy pulls a red air hose down from the ceiling and in- flates his space suit before he puts it on; this is stan- dard safety procedure. Mike steps right into his suit.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You forgot to test your suit. Look! It's torn. There is a small tear on the left leg of Gillespie's suit They both realize Gillespie's mistake could have cost him his life.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (beams ) If I let you die, who've I got to rag on? FADE UP the sound of furiously RUSHING AIR, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie and Berman, dressed in their BL-3 suits, stand in the air lock. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's no sound other than the FILTERED AIR RUSHING from a WALL JET into the long red tubing attached to the back of their helmets. These red tubes are called umbilical cords. Gillespie disconnects his, punches the wall plate and enters...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM OF LAB
dialogues.text: Quickly he connects to another umbilical cord; they hang from the ceiling at ten foot intervals. PAVAROTTI and SUTHERLAND singing the duet from "Lucia de Lamamoore" BLASTS from the SPEAKERS. Whenever Gillespie's in the lab, he's listening to opera. He approaches... The space-suited figure working under the hood. The figure turns and smiles; it's Salt. Gillespie's surprised. Salt salutes.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Colonel, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I thought you were doing your thesis at Walter Reede.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: A lot's been published on Herpes B but nothing on this new virus.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: So you were hoping to change subjects and get your name on my research papers?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Our research papers.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I would do my share of the work, sir. More.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: And you wouldn't have to worry about anybody publishing the same thing cause there ain't nobody else crazy enough to work with this dangerous a virus. Salt hesitates, then beams. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! Have you given the virus a name, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Motaba... after the valley where we found it.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I like it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Like it? Listen to the way it rolls off your tongue. Mo-ta-ba. Like a perfume. He lifts up a vial labeled MOTABA and puts it close to his body as if he's putting on perfume. Salt watches with horror. In spite of their BL-4 suits, you just don't play with these things. Salt checks Gillespie, expecting the same reaction, but... Gillespie's enjoying the moment. He expects these things from Berman. Izzy rubs the vial against his chest, savoring the experience.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: One drop and you feel... so different... Your lover will never recognize you again. (shoving the vial at Salt) Have some, Captain. Izzy tosses the vial of Motaba to Wally, who, terrified, doesn't know whether to catch it or not. But he does.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Good hands... That's important for working with level 4 viruses. Salt, trembling, notes that the vial is made of plastic.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: This plastic is unbreakable, right?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: So far. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A short, husky SPACE-SUITED FIGURE pushing a cart of test tubes round the corner. The name Owigatsuyama is embla- zoned above his breast, Sergeant Major stripes on his arm THROUGH his visor we see the face of a Japanese-American man in his early 60's with a warm friendly grin. We'll know him as Owi.

dialogues.speaker: OWI, (SPACE-SUITED FIGURE)
dialogues.text: (saluting Gillespie) Sir. (gesturing to Salt) He's here early. No coffee breaks.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Should we let this guy horn in on our new virus, Owi? Owi hesitates. Owl I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Well, that's that. Salt nervously eyes Izzy: "Is this a joke?"

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Captain, Sergeant Owigatsuyama here not only looks after everything in this lab, but since he knows the birthday of every great tenor and soprano who ever lived, Dr. Gillespie looks to him for supreme guidance on all matters.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Just a minute! I could've changed the radio to jazz. I love jazz. But I didn't. Whaddya haveta do to get on here?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Get me a blood test for the Motaba Virus.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: With a PCR catalyst I should be able to have a crude -- and I underscore crude -- screening test in a few weeks. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Excellent. But nobody's asking you to work a hundred and fifty hours a week...

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: A hundred and twenty will be plenty.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard, Captain. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford feeds flies to the Gila Monster. He looks out the office window at the BL-4 lab where Salt is working late. Ford moves on to the frog cages and feeds them too. He looks back at the BL-4 lab: sees Salt exiting. The lights go out. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford watches the bank of video monitors behind his desk: one shows Salt in the parking lot, getting into his old Fiat and leaving. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford, naked, slips on his suit with the ease of Joe Montana pulling on his helmet. He buckles the suit with- out even looking, as if he's done it five thousand times. FADE UP the sound of RUSHING AIR and... Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE'S BL-4 LAB
dialogues.text: Ford steps out of the air lock, disconnects his red hose and reconnects. He moves quickly across the room. Sud- denly, his air tube snags on the side of the lab bench. Ford stops, freaked. Quickly checks his hose. Indented, but not broken. He breathes again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: The world is round, Gillespie. Didn't anybody fucking teach you? He grabs a metal file off the tool board and files down the side of the bench until it's perfectly smooth and round. Then moves on to... One of the huge circular freezers in the center of the lab. He punches in a seven-digit code on the keypad and the LOCK SNAPS OPEN. He lifts the heavy lid. VAPOR RUSHES OUT. He looks inside, sees the 65 aluminum test tubes labeled "Motaba." Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: NEGATIVE PRESSURE HOOD
dialogues.text: opening one test tube after another, expertly withdrawing from each only a tiny sample of the virus, then putting i into a large test tube. Suddenly -- The air lock opens and three BL-4 figures approach Ford. We recognize the tall lean figure although he's 35 years older: McClintock, now a Lieutenant General. Ford hands him the large test tube.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Tell the boys the Old Man wants the answer tonight. McCLINTOCK Yes, sir. McClintock places the test tube into a clear plexiglass container which is contained within a large plexiglass container, each with its own combination lock. He twirls the tumblers. The LOCKS SNAP into place. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: GILA MONSTER
dialogues.text: Its eyes darting back and forth, ever watchful, trusting nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford leans on the bannister oblivious to the Gila Monster beside him. He's depressed and worried. In the distant sky,, traces of orange and pink announce the new day. From inside the office, a BEEP. Ford rushes...  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to his computer terminal. A message ratchets across the screen: "ANALYSIS FINISHED" He punches a computer key and swivels around in his chair to see the huge video screen on the wall. It shows two viral structures that look like DNA double helices. One is labelled "CD-40 1960 (Motaba Valley)"; the other is labelled "Motaba Virus - Gillespie - 1994." Letters flash across the screen. Ford puts on his horn-rimmed glasses and stares at the screen. He doesn't breathe. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: You fucker, why couldn't you stay dead? Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOTABA RIVER VALLEY
dialogues.text: Deep in the rain forest, a trapper wheels a cage contain- ing a baboon to a clearing where other trappers and Government Health workers have lunch. Scattered around them are cages filled with other animals they've caught for Motaba Virus testing. The DRONE of approaching PLANES builds. The animals hear it first and grow restless. The Army troops guarding the workers scan the sky but can't see the planes because of the treetops. They scream into their walkie-talkies. On the river, the Machine Gunner on the Army Patrol-Boat, hears their reports and swivels his cannon around, scan- ning the sky. But he can't see the planes either. The DRONE becomes DEAFENING. Suddenly: Over the treetops, three camouflage-painted DC-3 gunships emerge, CANNONS FIRING right on target. The Patrol Boat explodes into a shower of splinters. The DC-3 Gunships turn and arc high into the sky. On the ground the soldiers sight the planes. They OPEN FIRE but the planes are out of range. The ju-ju man comes out of his cave and watches the plane circle back and release a waxy grey cloud. The ju-ju Mmn raises his arms defiantly. He bares his teeth and screams, and his cry fuses with: (CONTINUED )
EXPLODING NAPALM. The planes press on relentlessly, extending the fireball mile after mile, extinguishing all life. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie bursts in. Ford looks up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: The rebels hit Iwabi's camp.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: I know. He swivels around in his chair to the world map on

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: They hit Kisangani, Bukavu, and Mbandaka as well. Three hundred thousand acres of forest burned, at least thirty-seven dead. I'm trying to find out about Iwabi.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: He's all right, thank God. He was in Kinshasha at his clinic but his entire field staff was killed. His whole lab destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Terrible.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I want to continue working on Motaba, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Look, as a scientist, I appreciate the fact that this one fascinates you --

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: -- It scares the shit out of me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: Colonel, the Pentagon's biting my ass cause we're months behind on the Anthrax studies. Get 'em finished. Take the heat off me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the wall. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then you can fiddle with Motaba as much as you like.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Sir, if this virus came to America --

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: -- Then it'd be outside our mandate. The CDC takes care of civilian problems. Christ, now you've even got me buying into your paranoia. We can't protect everybody against everything. We've got to make decisions based on the odds, and the odds of Motaba causing us any more trouble are a billion to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie, Salt and Izzy search through the round freezer

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Every sample of Motaba gone... Where the fuck did he put it? Owi looks contrite. Owl General Ford ordered me to move all tubes to the sealed vault in A wing... Only he has access. He said you weren't gonna need it for months. Gillespie and his men are despondent.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Those were the only samples in the world of Motaba, Iwabi lost all his in the fire. (to Owi) There's got to be a way to get that access code from Ford's computer. Owl Sir, I don't want any more trouble. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: OWI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's bad enough that I already made one mistake and forgot to transfer one of the tubes of Motaba. I seemed to have mixed it up with a tube of common cold virus. If I give you the tube, I'm sure you'll fix my mistake, sir. He reaches into his pocket and pulls out a gleaming aluminium test tube with the words "Motaba #48" written on the side.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I love it when you make mistakes, Owi. Owl How do you know? I never made one before now. Hold on their grins, FADE UP the sound of FURIOUSLY RUSHING WIND and: Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Dutch freighter plowing through the heavy seas. COMPUTER KEYS POUND: "THE DUTCH FREIGHTER APELDORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cramped dark hold, Betsy stares sadly through the bars of her cage at her captor, SEAMAN SECOND CLASS DIETER JANS, 21-years-old and making his first trip.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMAN JANS
dialogues.text: (in Dutch) What's the matter, girl? Dieter pushes a banana through the bar of the cage, and Betsy snatches it. Then she retreats with it to the far corner of the cage and studies Seaman Jans with plaintive eyes. PULL BACK to show the ship headed for the Golden Gate Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy stares out from her cage as it swings down from ship to wharf. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BIOTEST ANIMAL HOLDING FACILITY, (SAN JOSE, CALIFORNIA)
dialogues.text: We're in a long aisle with monkey cages stacked two high on both sides. A translucent skylight gives this place a greenhouse glow. A forklift putters down the aisle with Betsy's cage in front. Betsy's cage is lifted up and placed into a slot. Betsy stands out from all the other monkeys because she is the only black and white Colobos -- the other monkeys are all brown rhesus. Betsy's cage slides into place. BETSY SHRIEKS at the man in the forklift. JIMBO SCOTT, 23-years-young, long, scraggly hair, an aspiring rock and roll drummer working here to make ends meet. Jimbo's BEEPER SOUNDS. He checks the message, then looks puzzled. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimbo's red Nissan pulls up to the exit lane of the guard gate. The GUARD leans over.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimbo, I saw your band last night. Hot! I didn't know you were such a good drummer, man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Wait'll I get my new traps. The world'll never be the same. The Guard raises the gate and Jimbo drives forward. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: SIDE OF DARK ROAD
dialogues.text: Jimbo opens the trunk to reveal Betsy, drugged, asleep in her cage. Jimbo slides Betsy's cage out of the trunk and places it in the back seat. Cut TO:  40.

dialogues.speaker: INTERSTATE FIVE, (OREGON)
dialogues.text: Jimbo speeds along in his red Nissan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her cage in the back seat, Betsy moves back and forth restlessly, a baby bottle of water in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Cars put babies to sleep, why not you? Betsy takes a mouthful of water and spits it on Jimbo. His reaction is instant rage. He slams the cage:

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: You stupid fucking monkey! Why'dya wanna go and do that? He shoves the cage further away. Then he sees it - a small cut on his hand, caused by a couple of wire pro- trusions on the cage. He rubs the blood off on his shirt. The Nissan roars down the road. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPE
dialogues.text: A normal cell.

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A normal healthy liver cell. The image changes.

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Infected cell. The infected cell is swollen and filled with black brick- like structures.

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bricks of virus. They multiply until... The image changes: the bricks have completely overrun the cell, shattering its outer membrane so that bricks run rampant inside and outside the cell. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They explode the cell and destroy it. Then they move on to the next healthy cell. And the next. 'Til there's nothing left to kill. INT. BL-4 LAB - M.I.D.U. Gillespie, Berman, and Salt, dressed in their biosafety suits, peer at the video monitor hooked up to the electro microscope. Salt flicks a switch on the console to change the magnification. The fuzzy brick-like structures are computer enhanced and enlarged to razor-sharp crystal line structures that look like huge ominous steel balls climbing up the sides of thick pillars.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: There's our guy, Mr. Motaba.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Ugly bastard, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't let him date my sister. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPE FIELD
dialogues.text: as the image comes INTO FOCUS we see a wavy purple out- line of a cell.

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The blood test. Normal is this -- pure purple. But if you're infected... Focus changes and another image fills the screen: the field is filled with wide patches of red circles. Gillespie and Berman each peer into the scope.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: If you're red, you're dead. Is that what you're telling me?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: That's right, Colonel. The virus doesn't know the Cold War is over. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) But the rest is just a quickie; I haven't had time to refine it. There are false negatives, purples that should be red. I don't know why yet.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: How long to fix it?

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Hard to say.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Hey, don't pressure the kid! It took the NIH guys eight months to get the kinks outa the AIDS test... And they didn't have to put up with your nagging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillespie, Berman and Salt moving rapidly through the room within the BL-4 lab.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: This bug definitely ate its Wheaties.

dialogues.speaker: FOURTEEN CAGES
dialogues.text: each contains three or four different small mammals -- rats, guinea pigs, small lab mice, hamster, and rabbits. All stone dead.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It survives in air for twelve hours, and it survives in water for two hours.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Bullshit. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Hey, this little bugger's so hardy it can read the whole Sunday NY Times and not die, it can run the hundred in nine flat, and it can kill fish faster than my cat. Voila! 43. A fish tank with a dozen dead fish floating on top.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: No test species has survived, even when I've treated them with all antivirals, including every damn antiserum. What's even worse is there's a latency phase. Iwabi didn't see this in Zaire, I don't know why, but some of the animals I've tested had the infection a long time before they showed any symptoms. They even tested negative but had the disease. If this is true of humans... why we could have it ourselves and not know it.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Yet be spreading it.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: SALT
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST 31."
dialogues.text: Jimbo slides a cage containing Betsy into a space beside a cage containing a male brown RHESUS MONKEY. the bars of his cage and HISSES. He grabs Betsy cowers. RUDY ALVAREZ, the owner of the shop, slips on a pair of gloves and opens the cage, reaches in for Betsy. She tries to avoid his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: You got the papers and all? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... I got the papers. She's legal.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean 'she'? Betsy takes advantage of the opening and bolts out of the cage, heading for the window. As Rudy and Jimbo both chase after her, Rudy is steaming.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I told you a male.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: You said 'she'.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Bullshit! I said 'he'. The customer's already got a female Colobos. He wants to breed ‘em. Betsy slams against the glass. Rudy grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: C'mon, baby... c'mon. She lashes out at his naked forearm, digging her nails into him, drawing blood. He yelps and lets go, and she runs away to the other side of the room, passing the brown rhesus, who eyes a half-eaten banana in Betsy's cage. He grabs it and scarfs it down. Jimbo finally grabs Betsy from behind. Rudy grabs her from the front and they thrust her back into her cage. Rudy wipes the blood off his arm.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Get this bitch outa here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What about my money?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Go back and get me a male Colobos.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: We ain't got one. This was the only Colobos we had... Look, I'll sell her cheap.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't take her for free. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating the Brown Rhesus) I can't even sell this one.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: (depressed) Hey, I need some money now, man. Rudy hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: I done you a lot of favors. Rudy pulls out a billfold.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: All right... Fifty bucks for your expenses. A lot more when you bring me a male.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with her? Rudy shrugs. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: SMALL ROAD DEEP IN FOREST
dialogues.text: Jimbo opens the cage which is sitting on the side of the road by the Nissan, but Betsy shrinks back in a corner of the cage. Jimbo feels sorry for her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Look at all the trees. It's like home. Jimbo jabs her lightly with a drumstick. She runs out of the cage but stops at the edge of the road, afraid of the forest she doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: (flicking pebbles at her) C'mon, get. Get! She scampers off into the forest. Jimbo follows her with his eyes, a little saddened. Cut TO:  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimbo Scott is asleep against the window in the back row of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bang, bang! You're dead. Jimbo bolts up, and looks groggily at the four-year- old boy standing on the next seat: he's dressed in a cowboy's outfit with a huge sheriff's star pinned to his chest. He sneezes right in Jimbo's face. His mother puts down her Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Billy!? Say you're sorry. (to Jimbo) He's so excited; he's going to see his cousins.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOY
dialogues.text: My uncle's a real cowboy at a rodeo. Jimbo looks terrible. His eyes are red and he's having trouble swallowing. He grabs his pillow and blanket and gets up. Billy jabs his six guns into Jimbo's belly:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOY
dialogues.text: Where d'you think you're goin', mister?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Someplace they don't have lawmen. He goes to the back of the plane where's it's deserted, and lies down across three seats. His body shakes with a chill. He pulls the blanket tight against his chest. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: SEPTEMBER 1.
dialogues.text: The 757 glides almost silently over Boston Harbor as it sweeps in towards Logan Airport.  47.

dialogues.speaker: LOGAN AIRPORT
dialogues.text: Jimbo lumbers out and is greeted by a young woman with long scraggly hair who wears blue jeans and an old, faded T-shirt that says "Metallica." Her name is ALICE, and she puts her arm around Jimbo and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What'sa matter, honey?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Some little brat gave me his cold. She plants a kiss on him and pats his ass.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Too many late nights, that's all. Come home to bed. Jimbo smiles and pulls her close. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy's eyes glow in the moonlight. She looks hungry and sad. She hears the SHRIEK of a HAWK and freezes. These are foreign sounds. She moves stealthily across the forest floor. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAIN FOREST
dialogues.text: A patch of wild blackberries grow in a thicket. Betsy begins eating them ravenously. Then she HEARS SOMETHING and turns to see -- A coyote poised to leap. Betsy races up a pine tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COYOTE BARKS below. He's joined by his mate. The coyotes settle in for a long, hungry wait. Betsy is terrified. Cut TO:  48.

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAIN FOREST
dialogues.text: Betsy, still high up in the pine tree, looks down on -- The COYOTES, still waiting. One of them pricks up his ears and GROWLS. Suddenly a SHOT rings out, and the coyotes bolt. In the distance a hunter takes aim and FIRES again. Betsy cowers behind the tree, hiding herself from this new danger. The hunter runs under Betsy's tree, rifle in hand, cursing to himself, hell bent on killing the coyotes.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY IN TREE
dialogues.text: She waits as TWO more SHOTS ring out in the distance, then slowly climbs down.

dialogues.speaker: FOR DISEASE CONTROL, (CDC)
dialogues.text: DR. DREW REYNOLDS, 55, dressed in a doctor's coat, paces in front of a bookcase filled with medical tomes and topped by tennis trophies. Reynolds has a rest- less energy; he squeezes a tennis ball as he listens to Robby, sitting in a chair across from his desk, with a folder of fax papers in her papers. She's clearly intimidated by him, which is his intended effect on everyone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Dr. Gillespie wants us to send out a special bulletin warning all physicians to watch out for any symptoms of a virus from Zaire named 'Motaba.' He thinks it's serious enough to warrant emergency reporting nationwide, that it can't wait for our regular monthly report.

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Which will be released next week, correct?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Wednesday. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: To get out a special bulletin for four hundred thousand health professionals is about a hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Dr. Gillespie says it's the worst virus he's ever studied --

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: -- Forgive me, Robby, but this is the guy who found three cases of Congo Fever in Nairobi in '87, and suddenly it's in every American kid's lunch box --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: -- You're not being fair --

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: In '91 he said Tsutsugamushi Fever was coming. In '92 it was Ebola. His panics cost us plenty. Around here he's known as Doctor Doom.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: He could've been right about any of them. Rule out the worst first... that's what my father always taught.

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Your father was one of the greatest Surgeon Generals this country ever had. He took me under his wing and let me fly. I've always been grateful. And I've always had a special feeling for you, Robby. The... pain it gave him to see you working under Gillespie... all your promise... the man never gave you a chance to show it. A long silence. Drew has hit home.

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Look, is there a shred of evidence that Motaba is more transmissible than the other filoviruses we've seen in the past? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DREW REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Then as long as the bulletin goes out next week, we're covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: alone, very depressed, leans against the wall. We sense, if somebody walked in and said hello, she'd cry. The doors open into her floor and she gets out, not making eye contact with anyone. She enters...

dialogues.speaker: HER EXPANSIVE OFFICE
dialogues.text: Her young assistants, DR. JULIO SANCHEZ and DR. LISA ARONSON, faxes in hand, join her from their neighboring offices.

dialogues.speaker: LISA ARONSON
dialogues.text: An E-Coli outbreak in Michigan at a couple of Ronny's steakhouse franchises.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: And -- a couple of fevers of unknown origin at Boston Municipal that the infectious disease docs can't figure out. That's all we've got on the log.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (jesting) The Boston case is not some guy out of Zaire... with Motaba, is it?

dialogues.speaker: LISA ARONSON
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, right! Nah, it's a couple of Americans. No unusual travel.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: They've probably got some atypical strain of Lyme and the Boston doctors have just missed the boat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Then let's see if we can throw them a lifeline.  51.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: He doesn't look good, his face is flushed and sweaty, his eyes glassy. He turns the "Closed" sign around to "Open" and unlocks the door for an elderly lady, MRS. FOOTE, standing impatiently outside with her fat Persian cat in her arms. The BELL TINKLES as the door opens and she enters.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOOTE
dialogues.text: Rorshie didn't like the shredded veal wafers. I asked her and she said, 'Can we change it for the beef chips?' He's not up for this today.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOOTE
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Mrs. Foote... it's hot. That's all. Lemme open a win-- Suddenly his face twitches, his body stiffens, his eyes roll back and he falls to the floor, convulsing violently. Mrs. Foote screams. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: DR. MASCELLI, 43, a local G.P. auscultates Rudy's chest with his stethoscope. A nurse, EMMA, starts an IV. A second nurse, Jim, puts an oxygen mask over Rudy's face. The lab tech, HENRY, 23, very serious, wraps a tourniquet around Rudy's arm and draws some blood into three colored tubes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MASCELLI
dialogues.text: C'mon, Rudy, talk to me! No response. Dr. Mascelli rubs his knuckles into Rudy's chest. Rudy groans.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: They said he was fine yesterday. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. MASCELLI
dialogues.text: (rattled) And now he's in shock with pneumonia. (to Henry) Get me some blood cultures. Henry nods as he fills a lavendar-topped tube with Rudy's blood.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MASCELLI
dialogues.text: I've been reading about real bad strep cases. I bet this is one of ‘em. Emma, don't leave him alone. His heart could stop any minute. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: LAB
dialogues.text: spinning in a centrifuge. Henry turns it off. In the b.g., the RADIO BLARES with the MARINERS -- ANGELS game:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Johnson's ready... Checks the runners... Salmon is waiting. Johnson delivers. (a LOUD CRACK) That ball is hit. Deep... deep... it's gone. The Angels win!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Damn! Without thinking he reaches into the centrifuge, but it's still spinning. The lavendar tube shatters, spraying Rudy's blood everywhere. Henry squints. He's got blood in his eye. He rushes to the sink and washes it out. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ROOM OFFICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Mascelli trying to calm Henry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. MASCELLI
dialogues.text: You washed it out. Don't worry. But just in case, I'll put you on some penicillin prophylactically.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to give it to my girl friend.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MASCELLI
dialogues.text: (nudging Henry) Cheer up, the penicillin'1ll kill that, too. Henry manages a smile. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BONNEVILLE, OREGON
dialogues.text: Henry sits with his girl friend, CORINNE, watching a showing of the Warner-Kopelson blockbuster, Thief Of Araby. Henry starts to cough violently, then stands up.

dialogues.speaker: CORRINE
dialogues.text: Honey, what's wrong? He's sweaty and pale.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Just thirsty... Lemme get something to drink and I'll be okay. Henry heads up the aisle in the darkened theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry hits the concession stand line just as it's filling up before another movie in this multiplex. He's still coughing. He covers his mouth as he coughs again and again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Movie patrons, children and adults, on all sides of him are exposed to his "cold." HOLD ON each of their faces for a second as Henry pushes his way to the front of the line and grabs a handful of napkins.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Could I please get something to drink? TRACY, the salesgirl with a spiked haircut regards him with a hostile glance.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait your turn, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Please -- I'm not feeling too good. A large Coke. Or Pepsi. I don't care. At the front of the line, a black woman (MRS. LOGAN) with a streak of purple in her hair holds her toddler in her arms. She sees that Henry is ill.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LOGAN
dialogues.text: That's okay, let him go first. Henry, coughing violently, slaps down three dollars. Tracy serves him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry walks down the aisle with his drink in hand. He stumbles and falls forward, spilling the drink all over a MOVIE PATRON sitting on the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE PATRON
dialogues.text: Hey?! Watch what you're... When he sees Henry sprawled face down on the carpet, he's scared. He touches Henry's back:

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE PATRON
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy...? Usher!! Usher!!

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTERS KEYS POUND
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. Julio Sanchez from the CDC and THREE OTHER DOCTORS, dressed in full surgical smock, cap, foot covers, and gloves, stride briskly down the hall and approach double-doors marked "Quarantine: Protective Clothing Required" in red letters. They put on positive pressure respirator face masks and we hear the sound of RUSHING AIR. They push through the double-doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimbo lies near death in one bed, and his girl friend -- Alice lies near death in another. Plastic drapes have been placed over both beds, holding the air inside.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: The scarlet hemorrhagic rash can be seen on his cheeks. Blood trickles from his nose and his mouth, and soaks his sheets. Dr. Sanchez is shocked at how far gone Jimbo is.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (loudly) Mister Scott -- Jimbo... We're trying to figure out how you got this disease. It's important, so try to help me. You work at an animal facility in San Jose -- Jimbo's eyes are blank. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What's this guy got?

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: I don't know. That's why we'll need a post.

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No way. I'm not gonna slip and cut myself and get what he's got.

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Me neither. Suddenly from under her plastic protective shield, Alice stares over at Jimbo's bed. She calls out, her voice a whisper: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Jimbo -- Jimbo? Honey, are you all right...? Answer me, please. Alice has just spoken her last words. FADE UP the WHIR of a SUCTION PUMP and... Cut TO: INT. BOSTON MUNICIPAL HOSPITAL —- PATHOLOGY LAB Boston Doctor #3, in a biosafety suit, stares at Jimbo's naked body lying on the autopsy table. Dr. Sanchez, also in a biosafety suit, stands opposite.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Go very carefully, very slowly. Maximum sharps precautions. Sweat drips off Boston Doctor #3's face, fogging his visor. He starts to make the first cut, but his hand is trembling too much.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Don't let your eyes leave the blade. Ever. And you'll be okay. Doctor #3 cuts deep into Jimbo's ribs but no matter how slowly he cuts, the sharp edge of the scalpel seems too close to his fingers. PULL BACK to reveal they're doing the autopsy in a plastic tent using negative pressure suction pumps. As the PUMPS WHIR...

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Jesus -- the liver, spleen, kidneys -- they've turned into jelly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's as if they swallowed a bomb and it went off inside them. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know if it's Motaba but it sure looks like what Gillespie described.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: at her kitchen table. Petrified. We see she's been working late: her laptop's on, papers are strewn about.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (into phone) How many were exposed?

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Too many. The medical staff didn't know what they were dealing with so they didn't take precautions. They're scared outa their minds. Julio gazes through the glassed-in walls at the half- dozen pathology residents and nurses, peering at him with worried expressions. He spins around in his chair so he doesn't have to see them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: That's just the beginning. Patient zero -- this guy Jimbo Scott -- worked in an animal quarantine facility in San Jose, California. That's probably where he picked it up. Probably the whole place is infected by now and is gonna have to be nuked. (beat) It gets worse. Jimbo here takes a goddamn plane from Portland to Boston. The plane stopped in Chicago. Two hundred and eight people on the first leg, and Christ, something like two hundred and fifty on the second! If this guy was infectious, by now the whole country's been exposed. And Gillispie says there's no treatment for this mother, nothing to do but pronounce people dead. What are we supposed to do, Robby? Christ, what the hell are we supposed to do? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (coolly) Gillespie said Motaba only spreads by direct contact, that the disease isn't airborne. Was patient zero coughing? Sanchez flips through Scott's medical record. Robby has

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: I don't see anything about his coughing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Then the people on the plane are probably okay. But we're going to have to check every one of them out. Plus all the medical staff who worked on him and his girl friend. Plus all their recent contacts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: -- That's thousands of people --

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: -- I don't see a choice --

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: -- This whole hospital is buzzin' with rumors... it's gonna hit the press real soon. What are we gonna tell them?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: That the C.D.C. is investigating the situation, but we do not feel there's reason for alarm. I know it's scary, Julio, but the truth is we don't know what it is yet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Gillespie's the only one who can tell us. mixed emotions: the last person she wants to involve is her ex-husband.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Send him everything by stat courier.

dialogues.speaker: JULIO SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Got it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hangs up. STAY WITH Robby: her mind racing. She punches in a speed-dial key. An operator answers:

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Center for Disease Control.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Keough. Put out a stage three alert.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your password, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: Zebra, Apple, Charley, Kill. Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: WAR ROOM OF C.D.C
dialogues.text: A wan Drew Reynolds enters this large, frenetic room crowded with doctors and staff man the phone banks and fax machines that take up an entire wall. Along another wall is a huge electronic map of the U.S. A red circle blinks on Boston. Reynolds knows that if Motaba Virus rips through America, he's scapegoat number one. He makes his way to -- Robby at the large desk in the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Great! Now get the list of all his friends in San Jose. I want to know every contact the last last five days. She hangs up, turns to Lisa Aronson, on the phone at the next desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBY
